Pengguna WhatsApp Indonesia Korban Peretasan? Ini Kata Menkominfo
06 Nov 2019, 08:57 by Antara, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Menteri Komunikasi dan Informatika Johnny G Plate menyatakan tidak ingin berspekulasi bahwa Indonesia menjadi korban peretasan WhatsApp oleh perusahaan dari Israel, yang dikabarkan menggunakan nomor asal Indonesia.
"Nanti dicek dulu. Belum tahu, tidak bisa kira-kira, mesti yang pasti nanti," ujar Johnny, ditemui seusai acara "Gerakan Menuju 100 Smart City 2019" di Jakarta, Rabu, 6 November 2019.
Untuk mengantisipasi, Johnny mengatakan akan berkoordinasi dengan Badan Siber dan Sandi Negara (BSSN) dalam pertukaran informasi soal peretasan yang melibatkan WhatsApp dan perusahaan Israel tersebut.
"Iya kan BSSN lembaga negara, kita harus lihat dulu. Jangan berandai-andai dulu," kata dia.
Sebelumnya, kasus peretasan WhatsApp oleh NSO Group, yang melibatkan nomor seluler Indonesia juga sempat disinggung dalam rapat kerja Kominfo dengan Komisi I DPR RI, di DPR, Selasa (5/11).
"Pertanyaan saya apakah Kemenkominfo sudah lakukan investigasi soal ini atau belum. Kalau sudah hasilnya apa, dan tindakan yang sudah diambil apa untuk melindungi masyarakat Indonesia yang menggunakan WhatsApp," ujar Anggota Komisi I DPR dari Fraksi PKS, Sukamta.
Namun, peserta rapat menganggap jawaban atas kasus tersebut tidak perlu diberikan pada saat itu.
WhatsApp menuntut perusahaan teknologi asal Israel, NSO Group, karena membuat perangkat lunak spyware yang disisipkan ke server WhatsApp untuk meretas sejumlah pengguna mereka.
Perangkat lunak tersebut diduga berdampak pada 1.400 pengguna antara lain di AS, Uni Emirat Arab, Bahrain, Meksiko, India dan Pakistan, dikutip dari Reuters.
Pejabat senior pemerintahan di beberapa negara, terutama negara yang bersekutu dengan Amerika Serikat diduga menjadi korban peretasan ini.
India menyatakan korban peretasan termasuk jurnalis, akademisi, pengacara dan pembela komunitas di India.
Sejumlah media memberitakan peretas menggunakan nomor asal Indonesia dalam kasus ini.

WhatsApp Indonesia User Victims of Hacking? This is said by the Minister of Communication and Information
Nov 6 2019, 08:57 by Antara, Yudono Yanuar
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - The Minister of Communication and Information Johnny G Plate said he did not want to speculate that Indonesia became a victim of WhatsApp hacking by an Israeli company, reportedly using a number from Indonesia.
"You will have to check it first. Don't know yet, you can't, it must be certain later," Johnny said, met after the "Movement Towards 100 Smart City 2019" in Jakarta, Wednesday, November 6, 2019.
To anticipate, Johnny said he would coordinate with the Siber and Sandi Negara (BSSN) Agency in the exchange of information about hacking involving WhatsApp and the Israeli company.
"Right, BSSN is a state institution, we have to see it first. Don't assume," he said.
Previously, the case of hacking WhatsApp by the NSO Group, which involved Indonesian cellular numbers was also briefly touched on in a meeting of the Ministry of Communication and Information with the House of Representatives Commission I, at the Parliament on Tuesday (11/5).
"My question is whether the Ministry of Communication and Information has already investigated this matter or not. What results have been taken, and what actions have been taken to protect Indonesian people who use WhatsApp," said DPR Commission I Member from PKS Faction, Sukamta.
However, meeting participants assumed that the answers to the case did not need to be given at that time.
WhatsApp is suing Israeli technology company NSO Group for making spyware software that is inserted into the WhatsApp server to hack a number of their users.
The software is thought to affect 1,400 users including in the US, United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Mexico, India and Pakistan, as quoted by Reuters.
Senior government officials in several countries, especially those allied with the United States are suspected of being victims of this hack.
India claims victims of hacking include journalists, academics, lawyers and community defenders in India.
Some media reported that hackers used numbers from Indonesia in this case.
